Award.AwardTitle: The Dynamical and Chemical Basis for the Future of Pollution Extremes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Extreme air pollution events pose a considerable threat: it is estimated that currently air pollution is causing 7 million deaths annually and without action air pollution will also be the largest environmental cause of premature deaths by 2050. While meteorology sets the stage for the occurrence of dangerous pollutant levels pollution events do not occur in isolation but involve the interplay between the atmosphere's dynamical and chemical systems.

This project will bridge the gap between two separate lines of inquiry into extreme pollution events: one through studies of the dynamics of the atmosphere, the other through studies of atmospheric chemistry and aerosols. The relation between meteorological events and extreme pollution events is still not sufficiently understood. This research will further quantify this relationship, going beyond the proximal meteorological cause of extreme pollution events so as to understand these events within the context of the general circulation of the atmosphere.

Recent advances in the theory of atmospheric transport and mixing have shown the value of an objective diagnostic of the waviness of the jet stream and the associated synoptic cyclones and anticyclones as quantified through wave activity. Changes in wave activity and their relationship to air pollution events will be elucidated. These simplifying diagnostics have the potential to transform understanding of the relation between atmospheric circulation and air pollution events using dynamical insights into the underlying climate system. In particular they will allow a more robust understanding of how future climate will impact air pollution through changes in circulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Extreme events, can have an elevated impact on health and mortality. While receiving less attention than meteorological extremes, extreme air pollution events pose a considerable threat to human health. Pollution events do not occur in isolation but involve the interplay between meteorology and chemistry. This research aimed to examine this interplay and how it may change in the future. The research addressed the following: (i) the relationship between meteorological conditions, pollution events, and their future change; (ii) temperature and ozone distributions, their relation and processes that lead to extremes in the distributions; (iii) the impact of specific meteorological events on health and on climate.

Recent advances in the theory of atmospheric transport and mixing have shown the value of an objective diagnostic of the waviness of the jet stream quantified as wave activity.  Along with more traditional meteorological measures, we have examined the relationship between wave activity and surface pollution events using present-day and future model output from general circulation models and atmospheric measurements. Future wave activity changes over the United States can be pronounced, leading to local ozone changes between -6 and 6 ppb. Stagnant conditions are also likely to become more common in the future. The probability of high ozone extremes is considerably increased during successive days of meteorological stagnation.

Temperature has a strong impact on ozone photochemistry. Joint extremes in ozone and temperature may be particularly important as their joint impact on mortality is likely to be nonlinear. We have investigated the physical processes that determine temperature distributions and how these may change as CO2 increases. We have also investigated the relation between temperature and ozone extremes over the US for the present and future climate. At most at about a third of the time do extreme temperatures coincide with extreme ozone events. Future changes in high ozone extremes may range between +20 % and −10 % regionally over the US as the climate changes.

 Finally we investigated some particular events that lead to high pollution.  In particular we examined the US wildfires during the summer of 2017, a record breaking year in terms of wildfires (although it has recently be eclipsed by the summer of 2020). We found smoke from these fires decreased surface temperature by up to 2o C in parts of the Western US with a coincident decrease in the boundary layer heights of 80m. We also calculated the health costs of wild fires during 2017 due to the smoke emissions. We found these fires lead to approximately 400 premature mortalities, considerably more people than killed outright by the fires themselves.
